appearances.title: Power Lunch : CNBC : January 13, 2026 2:00pm-3:00pm EST
appearances.snippet: representatives lisa mcclain, jack bergman, john moolenaar, bill huizenga, tim walberg, john james and tom barrett. they're great people, every one of them. and as many of you remember, i came here at the height of the 2024 campaign to lay out my plan to bring jobs and factories and wealth racing back to the united states and coming back to the great state of michigan. and just a few weeks later, the people of this state and the voters all across the country endorsed that vision in a landslide victory we had. we won everything. we won all seven swing states. we won the electoral college 312 to 226. we won the popular vote by millions and millions of, oh, it's so nice to win the popular vote. i won the popular vote all three times too, but we're not going to get into that. but the first time they said i didn't win the popular vote, but i won the electoral college. so they always said, well, he didn't win. this is the way i got introduced every time. while he didn't win the popular vote, he won the electoral college, you know. so this is the way i was introduced for four years. and guess

appearances.title: U.S. House of Representatives U.S. House of Representatives : CSPAN : January 15, 2026 9:00am-12:22pm EST
appearances.snippet: representative bill huizenga. >> from michigan is recognized. >> well, thank you, mr. speaker. i appreciate my colleague from michigan granting me a little time here. i was not planning on speaking on this. i'm actually down here for an amendment, but the let me clean it up. mr. speaker, the hot garbage that we are hearing right now from the other side prompts me to address this. i'm vice chair of the financial services committee. one of our speakers earlier serves on that committee, where we regularly cross swords philosophically about what what the role of esg is. environmental, social and governance has been a hot topic, i can tell you that. and when he's when he's trying to compare what we're talking about today, this isn't an to to to what we're dealing with with some of the other retirement plans and publicly traded companies and what the sec has been doing. we're not talking apples and oranges, we're talking apples and pinecones. i mean, this is they might both grow on trees, but they're not anything like what is what the reality is. and he's talking about being a ceo. t
